title: Saltfleet Walks

images.title: Access to Saltfleet Haven by Peter Church, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Access to Saltfleet Haven

images.title: Simon Huguet / Dunes at Saltfleetby
images.caption: Dunes at Saltfleetby. The saltmarsh and the dunes are steadily accreting out towards the sea - the breakers can be seen lining the horizon. The dunes are part of the National Nature Reserve and are managed with cattle to maintain the plant diversity and prevent the site becoming scrubbed up with sea buckthorn and hawthorn.

images.title: Simon Huguet / Out on the Saltmarsh, Saltfleetby
images.caption: Out on the Saltmarsh, Saltfleetby

images.title: Alan Heardman / Rimac - View towards Zion Hill
images.caption: Rimac

images.title: Remains of a tank sinking into the sand by Richard Law, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Remains of a tank sinking into the sand

description: The village of Saltfleet is located on the Lincolnshire coast in the East Lindsey district of the county. It's an interesting and scenic place for a stroll with many listed buildings including a 13th century church, a 19th century windmill and two fine local pubs dating back hundreds of years. This walk from the village visits the Saltfleetby - Theddlethorpe Dunes National Nature Reserve. Also known as Rimac the reserve includes sand dunes, salt marsh, sand and mudflats with lots of interesting flora and fauna to see as well. Keep your eyes peeled for birds such as cuckoo, barn owl, redshank and shelduck as you make your way through the picturesque environment. You may also spot the rare natterjack toad if you are lucky. The reserve also includes the unusual and photogenic 'Tank on the Beach'. The Comet tank has been rusting for many years and lies half buried in the sand of the reserve. You could extend the walk by continuing south to neighbouring Mablethorpe where there are some attractive coastal gardens to explore. To continue your walking in the area head north to the Donna Nook Nature Reserve where you can see the grey seal population.

details.subtitle: Pubs/Cafes
details.content: The New Inn dates to the 17th century and serves good food at reasonable prices. They have a nice outdoor seating area and are dog friendly. You can find them at postcode LN11 7RZ.

display_address: Main Road, Bridge Farm, Skidbrooke with Saltfleet Haven, Saltfleet, East Lindsey, Lincolnshire, England, LN11 7SD, United Kingdom
